review.title: Enabling Medical Translation for Low-Resource Languages
review.abstract: We present research towards bridging the language gap between migrant workers in Qatar and medical staff. In particular, we present the first steps towards the development of a real-world Hindi-English machine translation system for doctor-patient communication. As this is a low-resource language pair, especially for speech and for the medical domain, our initial focus has been on gathering suitable training data from various sources. We applied a variety of methods ranging from fully automatic extraction from the Web to manual annotation of test data. Moreover, we developed a method for automatically augmenting the training data with synthetically generated variants, which yielded a very sizable improvement of more than 3 BLEU points absolute.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, Qatar's booming economy has led to a rapid growth in the number of migrant workers needed for the growing number of infrastructure projects; these migrant workers, mainly from southern parts of Asia, generally know little or no English and do not speak Arabic, creating a communication barrier between them and the locals, but the situation is more serious in the event of a medical emergency, causing serious problems as public administration and services in Qatar mostly use Arabic and English. According to a report by Weill Cornell Medical College (WCMC1) in Qatar [15], nearly 78% of patients attending Hamad Medical Corporation (HMC, the main healthcare provider in Qatar) do not speak Arabic or English. The study also pointed out that in 2012 (in this order) the five most spoken languages in Qatar are Nepali, Urdu, Hindi, English and Arabic. The report also pointed out that although HMC is currently using medical interpreters to overcome this problem, the number is not sufficient.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In the following, we first describe some MT applications for communication between doctor and patient. We then present more general research on MT for the medical field.

sections.heading: 2.1 Bi-directional Doctor↔Patient Communication Applications
sections.text: Most of them are still prototypes, and only a few have been fully deployed. Some of these systems work with poorly equipped languages [3,14,20,17]. Moreover, their solution relies on assigning the utterances to an interpreter rather than using SMT.MedSLT [3] is a language-to-language translation system. It covers a limited number of domains and covers English, Japanese, Catalan and Arabic. The system can translate doctor's questions / statements to the patient, but not the patient's reactions to the language-to-translation system.

sections.heading: 2.2 Uni-directional Doctor↔Patient Communication Applications
sections.text: In addition to the MT systems described above, there are a number of mobile or web applications based on pre-translated phrases, which are recorded by professionals or native speakers and can be played to the patient. Most of these applications only work doctor-to-patient. The most popular are UniversalDoctor2, MediBabble3, Canopy4, MedSpeak, Mavro Emergency Medical Spanish5 and DuoChart6. Unfortunately, these applications do not allow free, invisible or spontaneous translations and do not cover the language pairs that are of interest to Qatar. Another system [26] combined web-based monolingual data and a bilingual lexicon to complete the limited parallel corpora in domain. A third [34] proposed a terminology translation system for query translation as a subtask and used 6 different methods for terminology extraction. A fourth system [35] used a summary of sentence combinations based on COM, but not a medical combination system.

sections.heading: 3 Data Collection
sections.text: Since the main problem of resource-poor languages is data collection [24,30], we have taken a variety of approaches to collect as much parallel English Hindi data as possible.

sections.heading: 3.1 Wiki Dumps
sections.text: We downloaded, extracted and removed all language links from Wikipedia, 8 Wiktionary, 9 and OmegaWiki10 to enable one-to-one word mapping from English to Hindi. Subsequently, we extracted page links and language links from Wikipedia and Wiktionary. In addition, we used OmegaWiki to provide a bilingual dictionary containing the word, its synonyms, its translation and its lexical, terminological and ontological forms. We extracted the data using two OmegaWiki sources: bilingual dictionaries and an SQL database. Table 1 shows the number of Hindi words we collected from all three sources. 7 http: / / www.khresmoi.eu 8 http: / / www.wikipedia.org 9 http: / / www.wikipedia.org 10 http: / / www.omegawiki.org

sections.heading: 3.2 Doctor-Patient YouTube Videos and Movie Subtitles
sections.text: Since the use of automatic subtitling on YouTube is inefficient, the dialogs in the videos were first extracted by manually entering the audio found in the videos. However, as this process was very time consuming, we started a screenshot session to collect all the visual representations of the subtitles, and then the subtitles were extracted from the captured screenshots using Tesseract, an open source optical character recognition (OCR) reader provided by Google, manually corrected, translated into Hindi with Google Translate, and post-edited by a native Hindi speaker, resulting in a parallel corpus of medical dialogs with 11,000 Hindi words (1,200 sentences), which were later used to coordinate and test our MT system.

sections.heading: 3.3 BabelNet and MeSH
sections.text: We extracted medical terms from BabelNet [32] using its API. Since Medical Subject Headings (MeSH13) is the largest source of medical terms, we downloaded their dumps and extracted the 198,958 MeSH terms that we overlapped with the previously mined results from wiki dumps.

sections.heading: 4 Data Synthesis
sections.text: Hindi and Urdu are closely related languages that share a common grammatical structure and largely overlap in vocabulary, providing a strong motivation to transform an Urdu-English parallel file into Hindi English by translating the Urdu part into Hindi. We used the Urdu-English segment of the multi-parallel Indian corpus [36], which contains about 87,000 pairs of sentences. 11 https: / / github.com / tesseract-ocr 12 http: / / www.opensubtitles.com 13 http: / / www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov / meshOriginally, we trained an urdu-to-hindi SMT system using the tiny EMLE14 corpus [1].

sections.heading: 4.1 Interpolation
sections.text: Considering the Urdu-English phrase table p (u-i | e-i) and the English-Hindi phrase table p (u-i | h-i), we induced an Urdu-Hindi phrase table p (u-i | h-i) using the model [39,43]: p (u-i | h-i) = х e-ip (u-i | e-i) p (e-i | h-i) (1) The number of entries in the Urdu-to-Hindi phrase table was about 254,000. By interpolating, we were able to create a phrase table with about 10M phrases, reducing the number of OOV tokens from 310K to about 50,000.

sections.heading: 4.2 Transliteration
sections.text: Since Urdu and Hindi are written in different scriptures (Arabic and Devanagri, respectively), we have added a transliteration component to our Urdu-Hindi system. While it can be used to translate all 50,000 OOOV words, previous research has shown that transliteration is useful for more than just the translation of OOV words in the translation of closely related language pairs [29,31,38,41,42]. Following [9], we translate all Urdu words into Hindi and hypothesize n-best translations, along with regular translations. The idea is to create novel Hindi translations that are missing in the regular and interpolated phrase mapping, but there is evidence of this in the language model. Furthermore, the overlapping evidence in the translation and translation of phrase tables improves the overall system. We learn a clutter Hindi transliteration model [10] from word alignments of Hindi-Urdu-Urdu tables.

sections.heading: 5.2 Manual Evaluation
sections.text: In addition to the above evaluation, we conducted a small manual evaluation experiment using the appraise platform [16]. The following two sections describe the results of the Hindi-English (Section 5.2.1) and English-Hindi (Section 5.2.2) evaluations. Similar to evaluation campaigns such as WMT, the evaluators were shown the translations and references. 15 We used mkcls to group the data into 50 clusters, and the evaluators were asked to assign each translation to one of the following three categories: (a) helpful in this situation, (b) misleading, and (c) doubtful that people will understand it.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have improved our base system through two approaches, namely (i) additional data collection and (ii) automatic data synthesis. We have removed useful dictionaries from Wikipedia to improve the coverage of our system. We have used the kinship between Hindi and Urdu to generate Hindi-English-Bi synthetic texts by automatically translating 87,000 Urdu sentences into Hindi. Both our data collection and synthesis approach worked well and have shown significant improvements over the base system, resulting in a total improvement of + 3.11 BLEU points absolute for English-Hindi and + 2.07 for Hindi-English. In the error analysis of Hindi editions, we have found that most errors are due to the arrangement of the words in the output or to incorrect lexical selections. In future work, we plan to collect more data for the best system. In the error analysis of the Hindi edition, we have made the most errors attributable to the arrangement of the words in the output or the linguistic sequence.

metadata.abstractText: We present research towards bridging the language gap between migrant workers in Qatar and medical staff. In particular, we present the first steps towards the development of a real-world HindiEnglish machine translation system for doctor-patient communication. As this is a low-resource language pair, especially for speech and for the medical domain, our initial focus has been on gathering suitable training data from various sources. We applied a variety of methods ranging from fully automatic extraction from the Web to manual annotation of test data. Moreover, we developed a method for automatically augmenting the training data with synthetically generated variants, which yielded a very sizable improvement of more than 3 BLEU points absolute.
